register.description: IP revision identifier (X.Y.R) Used by software to track features, bugs, and compatibility
Information about the IP module's hardware configuration.

bitfield.description: Provides information to software if fragmentation support is available

register.description: Clock management configuration

bitfield.description: Configuration of the local target state management mode. By definition, target can handle read/write transaction as long as it is out of IDLE state.

bitenum.description: Force-idle mode: local target's idle state follows (acknowledges) the system's idle requests unconditionally, that is, regardless of the IP module's internal requirements. Backup mode, for debug only.
No-idle mode: local target never enters IDLE state. Backup mode, for debug only.

Smart-idle mode: local target's IDLE state eventually follows (acknowledges) the system's IDLE requests, depending on the IP module's internal requirements. IP module shall not generate (IRQ- or DMA-request-related) wake-up events.

register.description: Per-event raw interrupt status vector. Raw status is set even if event is not enabled. Write 1 to set the (raw) status, mostly for debug.

bitfield.description: The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
OCP error received in the master port.

register.description: Per-event 'enabled' interrupt status vector. Enabled status is not set unless event is enabled. Write 1 to clear the status after interrupt has been serviced (raw status gets cleared, that is, even if not enabled).

bitfield.description: The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.

The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.
OCP error received in the master port.

register.description: Per-event interrupt enable bit vector. Write 1 to set (enable interrupt). Readout equal to corresponding _CLR register.

bitfield.description: The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.

register.description: Per-event interrupt enable bit vector, line 0. Write 1 to clear (disable interrupt). Readout equal to corresponding _SET register.

bitfield.description: The WB physical window is ready to be accessed by the CPU.

register.description: Start address of the physical buffer of the CBUFF context 0. This register only exists when fragmentation support is enabled.
Start address of the physical buffer of the CBUFF context 0. This register only exists when fragmentation support is enabled.
Start address of the physical buffer of the CBUFF context 0. This register only exists when fragmentation support is enabled.

Context control register

bitfield.description: Sets the expected value for ADDR[32]. If ADDR[32]=TILERMODE, ADDR[31:4] is processed and eventually translated. Otherwise, the access is handled as transparent, regardless of the other address bits.

Write this bit to 1 to indicate the CPU has finished processing its physical buffer. This bit is automatically cleared by hardware, reads always return 0. This bit has no effect when MODE=2 (read/write)

bitenum.description: The CPU has completely processed the WB physical buffer.

bitfield.description: This register controls the bandwidth control feedback loop output. 0: Control loop disabled. 1-15: The control feedback loop enabled. Behavior depends on functional mode, see , .
Selects the functional mode of this context

bitenum.description: Write mode. ISS writes and CPU reads the physical space. CPU accesses are out of the scope of the CBUFF module; therefore, only writes are permitted between CBUFF_CTX_START__x and CBUFF_CTX_END__x.

Read mode. Hardware reads and CPU writes the physical space. CPU accesses are out of the scope of the CBUFF module; therefore, only reads are permitted between CBUFF_CTX_START__x and CBUFF_CTX_END__x.
Read/Write mode. Read and writes are monitored by the CBUFF. WB is used to track current read positions WA is used to track current write position.

Disables the context. This resets the internal state of the context. All accesses received on OCPI are transmitted to OCPO without modification. Disabling the context takes effect immediately. Software must ensure that no more accesses to the context are outstanding before disabling it. Otherwise memory corruption may occur.
Enable the context. All accesses between CBUFF_CTX_START__x and CBUFF_CTX_END__x are processed by the CBUFF.
